credentials: PHD 1992 Univ of California Santa Cruz
name: Russ CASTRONOVO

ratings.comment: At first, the class may seem like a lot of work and reading, but Professor Castronovo makes class interesting enough so it does not feel like work. He is extremely kind and is always accessible outside of class. Visit his office hours and he is more than willing to help you through every step of your writing process.

Professor Castronovo led one of the most interesting classes I have ever taken. Lots of reading, some writing, but it is very much worth it. Impacts both your writing and thinking skills. Cannot recommend enough but be prepped for a moderate workload.

Professor Castronovo leads insightful class discussions and makes literature interesting by tying it into current events. But, be prepared to write very often (1-2 short essays per week) and participate consistently in class to get a decent grade. Do not take this class if you think it will be side work to satisfy credits.

Great professor that increased my understanding of course content and helped me become a better writer. The professor was very approachable and helpful when discussing ideas for assignments. Overall, would highly recommend the professor as he makes the class interesting and is very knowledgeable on the course content.
Castronovo was insightful and overall a good professor. Not an easy class, but one that provoked thought.

Awesome professor. Extraordinarily difficult, but one of the best professors I've had here. It really pays off (in terms of both grades and personal improvement) to go to office hours to discuss papers. I can say without a doubt that he helped to improve my writing ability.

Best teacher I've had here. Very tough but will work with students individually to improve. If you work hard, grades can be based on improvement. Extremely thought-provoking discussions in class. Expects participation. He knows when you haven't read something.

Incredible professor. Thought provoking, and he makes extremely challenging reading accessible though class. Is extremely helpful outside of class too, so make sure to take the opportunity. Brilliant.

Go to office hours for papers if you want a decent grade (it makes a difference!) He really focuses on close readings, and don't add to the discussion unless you have something to say. I had him for a FIG. Not what I was expecting! Loves democracy & race issues. Do the reading, mark what he brings up in class, and you'll do fine on the essay tests.

Castronovo blends irony, wit, and insight.  It's clear he works hard on his lecture, perhaps because he's so into the idea of democracy.  He's kinda crazy, too (he really gets into it), but in a good way.

Great class, although I wouldn't recommend it first thing in the morning. However, Castronovo really woke you up - he has so much life, character, adn energy, you can't be bored with the class. The readings are long and difficult, but the discussions are well worth the time and effort. Castronovo is definitely worth a shot.

Quite possibly one of the worst professors I've ever had. I went to every boring lecture, but hardly saw the point in going. Each one was merely a study in closing reading of the texts. I learned next to nothing about American literature and almost none of the reading list was the traditional canon.

One of the greatest teachers at this University.  He's passionate about his work and expects a lot from his students.  This is not a push-over class, so if you're looking for an easy A, this is not your ideal teacher.  He'll make you think and question everything you know about American culture, truly inspiring.
Most interesting class I have ever taken at Madison.  He has a very interesting perspective on American culture and executes class discussions well.

I had him for modernism/post-modernism class in college, and it was probably my single favorite academic class. The reading materials were wide-ranging and fairly challenging, but the discussions were great and he seemed passionate about the class.
Sea of madness?  Should I say "more like a ship of fools" or is that too obvious?
The class was basically a sea of madness, but it was really interesting and entertaining.  The readings were hard, but he randomly threw in fun things that kept everyone interested.
